snippet.description: The concept of resilience offers a holistic approach for understanding and managing complex island systems, and problems such as climate change.  In this talk, Paul and Nadine Marshall discuss how the concept of resilience can be applied to real-world settings through examining its functional opposite, vulnerability.  Through recognizing the links between ecological and social vulnerability, we can gain insight into the needs, aspirations, and dependencies of people, and integrate those into decisions we make about natural resource management and adaptation planning.
snippet.title: Navigating an era of unprecedented change

snippet.description: In this talk, Stacy Jupiter of the Wildlife Conservation Society presents two case studies of traditional Pacific Island practice that can provide lessons for building or maintaining socio-ecological resilience.  The first case focuses on the differential impacts of Cyclone Ofa on agricultural resources in Samoa and how resilience was promoted through traditional systems of farming.  The second case presents the evolution and customary tenure and temporary fisheries closures in Melanesia as a strategy to manage relationships and build alliances among social groups.
snippet.title: Pacific Island socio-ecological resilience

snippet.description: In this talk, Katerina Teaiwa presents the experience of the Banabans, who were displaced en masse from their home island in Kiribati to the island of Rabi in Fiji as a result of extensive colonial phosphate mining.  While the Islanders eventually developed creative strategies for living in new environmental, cultural, and sociopolitical contexts, they continue to face significant challenges.  Their experiences provide critical lessons for what is now viewed as impending climate change-induced displacement from other islands in Kiribati and Tuvalu in the not-too-distant future.
snippet.title: Banabans of Ocean Island and Rabi

snippet.description: Decades of human and natural pressures have reduced Caribbean reefs to a shadow of what they once were.  However, the Cordelia, Smith, and Capiro Banks of Honduras maintain a great deal of live coral coverage despite multiple threats including overfishing, nutrient pollution, and increasing ocean temperatures.  The Coral Reef Alliance, Roatan Marine Park, Healthy Reefs Initiative, and other local organizations have come together to cooperatively manage these reefs and support their resilience.  Together these groups are working with the Honduran government to strengthen a network for Marine Protected Areas in the Bay Islands.
snippet.title: Resilience Systems in the Bay Islands

snippet.description: Alarming long-term trends in reef degradation identified by the Hawaii Division of Aquatic Resources spurred an education and outreach campaign that ultimately led to the designation of the Kahekili Herbivore Fisheries Management Area.  Long-term coral reef monitoring data coupled with innovative herbivore management efforts have resulted in national recognition and the designation of West Maui's watersheds as the priority Pacific watershed by the U.S. Coral Reef Task Force.  This case study provides an ideal example of how social change can occur when people are actively involved in the resource management process.
snippet.title: Managing for resilience using community engagement

snippet.description: Coral reefs provide numerous ecological benefits that are critical to social and economic welfare for island nations.  Widespread overfishing has led to a decline in states of ecosystem health, decreasing ecosystem resilience, and the ability of coral reefs to support future economic and social needs.  Assessing and managing for ecosystems and fisheries that are in less desirable states has been challenging - specifically in island nations where data for assessing fish stocks and ecosystem status is limited.  This talk by Kendra Karr of the Environmental Defense Fund proposes a framework to produce rapid, precautionary, and adaptive management guidance for a broad range of fisheries varying widely in data richness.
snippet.title: Managing data-limited fish stocks

snippet.description: Leaders of island nations struggle to find the balance between conserving and developing; when islands are faced with a decision between poverty and natural resource conservation the choice is not so easily made.  How then do we motivate and inspire people to invest in natural resource conservation - a huge investment with slow yields?  How do we demonstrate that this investment and commitment has a solid future in light of climate change, food security, and poverty?  Striving to conserve natural resources for the benefit of island people's way of life and economic security requires a high level of collaboration across cultures and political divides.
snippet.title: Managing identity in the midst of globalization

snippet.description: This panel discussion brought scientists and managers together to explore the impact that scientific knowledge has on decision-making for local managers.  Panelists discussed how scientists can work with managers to relay information, and how scientists can incorporate managers' needs into their work.
snippet.title: Panel Discussion: science and management

snippet.description: Managing reefs for resilience to climate change is critical as the frequency and severity of bleaching events is predicted to increase.  However, little guidance is available on how to interpret and use resilience data to inform management.  The Nature Conservancy's Sangeeta Mangubhai and colleagues developed a framework for interpreting this research data and its usefulness in decision-making, making it easier to identify potential management actions that will increase resilience.
snippet.title: Managing reefs for resilience framework

snippet.description: Coral reefs globally are declining while climate change impacts on reefs are intensifying.  A growing interest to promote resiliency is a way forward in managing reefs.  In this talk, Naneng Setiasih discusses the Coral Reef Alliance-led trainings for local managers and recreation providers in Bali and Mexico, designed to improve local capacity in the management of reefs.
snippet.title: Building local reef resilience capacity

snippet.description: The Islanders of Lakshadweep are extremely dependent on coral reefs and associated resources.  Outside influences including tourism, commercialism of the fishing sector, and globalization are leading to significant changes in the Islanders' cultural norms.  Socioeconomic divides are growing, and despite high literacy rates only 6% of Agatti Islanders have completed high school.  These trends create challenges and emphasize the need to implement environmental policies for management of local resources and generate support to ensure long-term viability of the reefs.
snippet.title: Case study of Lakshadweep

snippet.description: This case study retraces the implementation and development of integrated management in Taiarapu, based on an old Polynesian custom called rahui.  Traditionally, rahui is a sacred decision to protect an area or resource whether on land or lagoon.  In order to strengthen the legal basis of the new rahui system created by the district of Teahupoo, the community created a hybrid governance model, incorporating traditional expertise with state legal framework.
snippet.title: Protected Areas in Taiarapu, Tahiti

snippet.description: This discussion addresses the unique characteristics that enable resilience in the Solomon Islands in the face of rapid globalization, shifting climates, changing ocean processes, and local ecologies.  Panelists talked about the need to strategically manage for resilience in the Solomons, and lessons learned from social and ecological resilience efforts.
snippet.title: Panel Discussion: Resilience in the Solomon Islands

snippet.description: Islands are famous as crucibles for processes of adaptation and diversification, but they are also naturally conducive to small populations whose lack of genetic diversity can impede adaptation.  This talk by Scott Edwards of Harvard University reviews basic processes of population genetics and evolutionary divergence that influence the prospects of resilience on islands, and how managers and policy-makers can develop strategies to maximize the influx of new genetic variation.
snippet.title: Evolutionary processes fostering resilience on islands

snippet.description: There are two crucial actions to help conserve marine ecosystems around islands - managing fishing and managing runoff from the land.  This presentation by Hugh Possingham shows recent examples of methods to decide where to take conservation action, focusing on the potential conflict between equity and prioritization.  How much does equity between communities or industries constrain the most effective conservation outcome?
snippet.title: Conservation priorities for island ecosystems

snippet.description: The windward reefs of Tobago represent the most robust and resilience systems on the island, considered to be of high cultural and conservation value.  However, these reefs remain unprotected from manageable human impacts such as agricultural runoff, overfishing, and hillside runoff.  While the area offers strong recreational and economic opportunity for sustainable development to the community, the site is highly vulnerable to climate change impacts.  A year-long community-based management project led to the formation of the Speyside Eco-Marine Park Rangers, dedicated to community co-management of natural resources to support sustainable livelihoods for the Speyside community.
snippet.title: Socio-ecological resilience in Tobago

snippet.description: Following a severe thermal anomaly in 2010, Reef Check Indonesia, The Nature Conservancy, and Wildlife Conservation Society conducted reef resilience assessments and coral bleaching monitoring at 26 sites in Bali and Lombok, Indonesia.  The highest resilience was found in Amed, a popular tourism destination in eastern Bali.  A local management plan focuses on reducing local threats, unregulated tourism, anchoring and destructive fishing practices, and littering.
snippet.title: Climate change adaptation in tourism destinations

snippet.description: Identifying sites with high resilience potential can inform a range of management decisions to support and maintain coral reefs.  A framework has been published outlining 11 variables that can be evaluated to compare the resilience potential of reef sites.  This talk by Steven Johnson of the CNMI Division of Environmental Quality presents the results of the first field-based implementation of the framework from 35 sites around Saipan, and how methods presented in the framework help to prioritize resilience indicators.
snippet.title: Coral reef resilience in Saipan, CNMI

snippet.description: When discussing small islands and climate change a commonly-held view is that sea level rise represents an existential threat to low-lying coastal communities.  Carlos Mondragon presents a case study of the Torres Islands in the Western Pacific, subject to dramatic shifts in coastal sea levels due to seismic activity.  The Torres society has developed resilience to potential threats by incorporating traditional wisdom and practices into effective planning and management, allowing the culture to survive and thrive.
snippet.title: Notes from a floating island

snippet.description: This presentation by Meghan Gombos of Sea Change Consulting discusses tools to support community-based adaptation developed by partners in Pacific Island organizations.  The first, "Adapting to a Changing Climate Toolkit," provides communication materials and a low-tech adaptation planning process for communities.  The second tool, "Designing Resilient Locally Managed Areas in the Tropical Marine Environment: A Guide for Community-Based Management Practitioners," is focused on providing the most recent, up-to-date science on marine technology and management for supporting fisheries, resilience, and biodiversity.
snippet.title: Community-based adaptation in Pacific Islands

snippet.description: Western representations of "disappearing island nations" are often characterized by unhelpful alarmism and assumptions of inevitable resettlement.  In recent years, climate vulnerability researchers in the Marshall Islands have devised communication strategies that present their findings while avoiding the negative connotations.  In the community of Rita the residents have enacted an ambitious climate change resilience program to demonstrate the necessity and feasibility of culturally sensitive, community-based approaches to meeting the environmental challenges of the 21st century.
snippet.title: Case study of Rita Reimaanlok

snippet.description: Coral reefs in Southwest Puerto Rico and worldwide are experiencing increased threats due to climate change and ocean acidification.  Additionally, increasing human populations and efforts to maximize agricultural production generate pollution that compromises the integrity and resilience of Puerto Rican coral reefs.  This talk discusses the efforts to restore ecological systems and services by implementing a shade planting regime in degraded sun coffee farms.  These efforts in Guanica are a test case for helping create a sustainable local economy that simultaneously promotes restoration and resilience in coral reefs.
snippet.title: Resilience in Guanica, Puerto Rico

snippet.description: Ciguatera poisoning is a critical public health issue among Pacific Island nations.  The ability to accurately predict ciguatera outbreaks has become a priority, particularly in Rarotonga in the Southern Cook Islands - a location reported as having the highest incidence of ciguatera poisoning in the world.  Teina Rongo's talk discusses the relationship between cases of ciguatera poisoning, coral cover, herbivorous fish densities, and reef disturbances.
snippet.title: Ciguatera poisoning in Rarotonga

snippet.description: In 2009 the Indonesian government and local communities established five Marine Protected Areas to protect marine biodiversity and ensure sustainable fisheries in Raja Ampat, West Papua.  Using traditional management practice known as sasi, local people in Raja Ampat can open and close areas or ban the collecting of certain fish species.  By including sasi areas into the Raja Ampat MPA network, fisheries resources can recover over time with the active engagement and support of the local community.
snippet.title: Local wisdom and resilience in Raja Ampat

snippet.description: The United Nations recognizes 52 Small Island Developing States - 38 Member States and 14 Associate Members of Regional Commissions.  These states are vulnerable to ecological and socio-economic threats, and need to take action at all levels for sustainable development.  The UN Office of the High Representative for Least Developed Countries, Landlocked Developing Countries, and Small Island Developing States works to promote collaborative partnerships that respect local needs and priorities.
snippet.title: Fostering manager voices to inform global policy

snippet.description: This panel discussion brought funders and local managers together to discuss various aspects of funding to promote resilience in island and coastal systems in the face of globalization, climate change, and manmade threats to ecosystems.
snippet.title: Perspectives on funding for resilience
